title: Scoob!
description: In Scooby-Doo’s greatest adventure yet, see the never-before told story of how lifelong friends Scooby and Shaggy first met and how they joined forces with young detectives Fred, Velma, and Daphne to form the famous Mystery Inc. Now, with hundreds of cases solved, Scooby and the gang face their biggest, toughest mystery ever: an evil plot to unleash the ghost dog Cerberus upon the world. As they race to stop this global “dogpocalypse,” the gang discovers that Scooby has a secret legacy and an epic destiny greater than anyone ever imagined.

I found this new Scooby-Doo movie, the first to use computer animation, to be good but with room for improvement.Let me get this out of the way for Scooby-Doo fans: This isn't the traditional type of story. There isn't a lot of mystery solving or spooky situations. This is more of a superhero adventure. Warner Bros. (which now owns Hannah-Barbera) is trying to start a shared HB universe. So they were more interested in doing a movie using HB characters from more than one show. Scooby was basically chosen as the first lead because he's the most prevalent character.Shaggy (voiced by SNL/Last Man on Earth's Will Forte) and Scooby (voice-acting veteran Frank Welker) spend a lot of the show working with other HB characters in order to push the shared universe concept. The rest of the Mystery Inc. characters only play supporting roles. I would've preferred the main gang in more of this, but I give the movie credit. This isn't the only SD show or film to focus on just the duo, but I felt that this was the only one where they managed to make it work. (That's right Reluctant Werewolf fans, come at me.)This may not be a perfect representation of what Scooby-Doo is, but as a movie by itself it's an entertaining children's film. It doesn't have the most ambitious story, but it's fun and upbeat. (I ended up watching this twice.) The best part is the jokes, there are a lot of funny lines.There are a lot of moments where I felt myself thinking that the movie could have been stronger. The setup in the first few minutes feels rushed. The movie offers an obstacle to Scooby and Shaggy's friendship and confidence, which feels formulaic and forced. However, when it comes to their and other characters' emotional moments, the movie nails it perfectly; no complaints.Some of the voice actors felt miscast. (Jane the Virgin's Gina Rodriguez sounds too old to be Velma.) Others were good, but couldn't quite make the dialogue pop. The MVP in this is Jason Isaacs, who played Lucius Malfoy in Harry Potter, as Dick Dastardly. He completely encaptures the feel of old-timey mustachoid villainey.The animation is cheaper than say a film from Disney, Dreamworks, or Pixar. (Given how their attempt to create a DC shared universe didn't pan out, I can't blame the WB for being financially cautious. Even the director Tony Cervone was brought from within house.) That having been said, design-wise the entire thing looks great. There is a distinctive colorful look to this. Several characters get redesigned. I know some people don't like it when they mess with characters' classic looks, but I really, really liked how everyone appeared. Really, the design team knocked it out of the park.I know my jaded adult mind has been critical of this. Plus this isn't my, or probably many other adult SD fans, idea of the ideal Scooby film. (Scooby-Doo on Zombie Island is still the high bar to judge by.) But, I'm pretty sure kids won't have any complaints from this. Plus, I think this won't bug parents if their children rewatch. This is a perfectly decent way to spend your time.

E-Value: 7Acting: 8Plot: 5After two terrible live action movies and many direct-to-video movies, Scooby-Doo franchise returns to the big screen and this time in an animated movie. This movie is the first instalment in the planned Hanna-Barbera shared universe. Originally, the movie would have release in the big screen if it weren’t for the COVID-19 pandemic. Instead, the movie goes straight to video on demand.The movie begins with Shaggy (Forte) meeting a stray dog, whom he named the dog, Scooby-Doo (Welker). Soon, they become close friends. During Halloween, they meet Fred Jones, Daphne Blake and Velma Dinkley where they catch a costumed thief who have been stealing many electronic devices. This inspires them to work together as a team known as Mystery Inc.Ten years later, a British entrepreneur decides to do business with Mystery Inc as its investor but he would not invest if Shaggy and Scooby are part of it because he claims that friendship is a weakness. Angered by his words, Shaggy and Scooby leave and hang out in a bowling alley where they were attack by small robots called Rottens.They were later rescue by the Blue Falcon, Dynomutt and Dee Dee Sykes in a nick of time, whom they told them those robots work for a super criminal named Dick Dastardly (Isaacs). Dastardly wants Shaggy and Scooby for reasons unknown but it has something to do with the three skulls of Cerberus, which he has been stealing them. Meanwhile, Fred along with Daphne and Velma soon tracks down Shaggy and Scooby and they work on their own in solving the mystery to find out what is Dastardly’s plan.I may not a big fan of Scooby-Doo franchise but Scoob! is a fun and enjoyable movie to watch. The animation and character design are very well done and the voice acting are great. There are lots of funny moments and the humours are not weak and lousy. Although none of the original cast of the previous Scooby-Doo movies (except Frank Welker) returned to voiced their respective characters, everyone in this movie still delivered their best performance. As for Will Forte, he managed to gave his best voice acting for Shaggy. At least, it is a good thing that Shaggy does not sound terrible. However, I wish Matthew Lillard would reprise his role. It would have been great service for hardcore fans of the franchise.While I enjoyed watching the movie but the story in this movie have some flaws. As this is the first instalment in a shared universe, the movie used up too many characters outside of Scooby-Doo franchise. Because of this, Scoob! became more a Hanna-Barbera crossover movie instead of a Scooby-Doo movie. The movie should have focus on mystery solving stories like how every other Scooby-Doo TV shows and movies have done previously. Honestly, the movie should have been full origin story with Scooby-Doo characters only. The crossover stories should have been save for future instalments. One thing good about this movie is Scoob! did not go overboard with setting up some future instalments like the 2014’s The Amazing Spider-Man 2 and 2017’s The Mummy.For those who are fans of Hanna-Barbera, you probably will enjoy watching this movie but those who are Scooby-Doo fans, you may or may not like this movie. For the time being, we can only wait and see if this movie will be success. If it does, there might be a sequel to this movie or more Hanna-Barbera movies will be made. If not, this will the only instalment in Hanna-Barbera shared universe. Only time will tell. In the nutshell, this is a mediocre movie. Not too good but it is not too bad either. You can give this movie a shot if you are curious.

Para minha surpresa, a obra foi completamente "assistível".O humor é bem claro no que se diz respeito ao publico alvo, porém, ainda há algumas piadas e referencias que ao menos tiraram um riso do meu rosto. Os personagens não são bem desenvolvidos. Porém, pelo fato de serem não só rostos mas personalidades conhecidas, o filme não precisa se esforçar muito para que gostemos deles. O mesmo diz respeito ao vilão e a outra equipe que os ajudam. Acho que a presença deles foi interessante e divertida. O filme também possui umas subtramas bobas que deixam a experiencia mais leve e fora do foco. A animação está lindíssima - eles acertaram em cheio na caracterização dos personagens também. Ninguém soou estranho aqui.Essa não é uma animação que agrega muito - o que vem sendo pregado pela pixar e disney há muito tempo, porém, ainda sim da pra passar o tempo, principalmente se quem estiver assistindo for uma criança.
